Submodules

peapy.component module

class peapy.component.Component

Bases: object

The component class. Components are used to add functionality to game objects.

init()

Called when the component is added to the game object.

init_(game_object: object)

Used by PeaPy to initialize the component. Don’t call this manually or override it. Use the init() method instead.

Parameters

game_object – The game object.

update() → bool

Update the game.

Returns

True if the game should continue, False if the game should end.

update_() → bool

This method is called by PeaPy to update the component. Don’t call this manually or override it. Use the update() method instead.

Returns

True if the game should continue, False if the game should end.

peapy.config module

class peapy.config.Config(from_dict: Optional[dict] = None)

Bases: object

Used to pass configurations to the PeaPy constructor.

to_string(tab_level: int = 0) → str

Return a string representation of the Config object.

Parameters

tab_level – The number of tabs to add to the beginning of each line.

Returns

A string representation of the Config object.

peapy.config.get_default_config() → peapy.config.Config

Get the default configuration.

Returns

Config

peapy.game_object module

class peapy.game_object.GameObject(name: str)

Bases: object

The GameObject class is the base class for all game objects. GameObjects are used to represent things in the game world (for example the Player).

add_component(component: peapy.component.Component) → peapy.component.Component

Add a component to the game object.

Parameters

component – The component to add.

Returns

The component that was added. This allows for the following patterns: component = game_object.add_component(Component()) or game_object.add_component(Component()).do_something()

get_component(name: str) → peapy.component.Component

Get a component by name.

Parameters

name – The name of the component to get.

Returns

The component.

get_components() → dict[str, peapy.component.Component]

Get all components.

Returns

A dictionary of all components.

init()

Called when the game object is added to the game.

init_(peapy: object)

Used by PeaPy to initialize the game object. Don’t call this manually or override it. Use the init() method instead.

Parameters

peapy – The PeaPy instance.

remove_component(name: str)

Remove a component from the game object.

Parameters

name – The name of the component to remove.

update() → bool

Update the game object. This method is called every frame.

Returns

True if the game should continue, False if the game should end.

update_() → bool

This method is called by PeaPy to update the game object. Don’t call this manually or override it. Use the update() method instead.

Returns

True if the game should continue, False if the game should end.

peapy.peapy module

class peapy.peapy.PeaPy(config: peapy.config.Config = window: width: 800 height: 600 title: Peapy icon: icon.ico colors: background: #000000)

Bases: object

The main class of the game engine.

add_game_object(game_object: peapy.game_object.GameObject) → peapy.game_object.GameObject

Add a game object to the game.

Parameters

game_object – The game object to add.

Returns

The game object that was added. This allows for the following patterns: game_object = game.add_game_object(GameObject()) or game.add_game_object(GameObject()).do_something()

get_game_object(name: str) → peapy.game_object.GameObject

Get a game object by name.

Parameters

name – The name of the game object to get.

Returns

The game object.

get_game_objects() → dict[str, peapy.game_object.GameObject]

Get all game objects.

Returns

A dictionary of all game objects.

remove_game_object(name: str)

Remove a game object from the game.

Parameters

name – The name of the game object to remove.

update() → bool

Update the game.

Returns

True if the game should continue, False if the game should end.

peapy.utils.tree(game: peapy.peapy.PeaPy)

Print a tree of game objects and their components

Parameters

Module contents

An easy-to-use Python game engine.
